data.event: In 1824 the United States Congress passed the General Survey Act, intended to create and maintain military roads through what was then the west of the country.
Also in 1824, the land around today's Manchester was surveyed by John Mack, who noted it as being "a good mill seat."

event.title: agreed with John Mack, and on May 10, 1826

data.event: John Gilbert, who had recently completed work on sections of the Erie Canal, agreed with John Mack, and on May 10, 1826 he purchased 80 acres (32 ha) of land along the Raisin River at that location.
Originally from upstate New York, John Gilbert resettled to Ypsilanti, Michigan, in 1831.
In 1832, he decided to turn his attention to the extensive land tracts he held in the area.
He commissioned the construction of a grist mill along the Raisin River upon the land he had purchased in 1826.

event.title: was prepared by surveyor Hiram Burnham and dated 1833

data.event: The original plat of the village of Manchester was prepared by surveyor Hiram Burnham and dated 1833, but was not formally filed until March 25, 1835.

event.title: was not formally filed until March 25, 1835

data.event: The original plat of the village of Manchester was prepared by surveyor Hiram Burnham and dated 1833, but was not formally filed until March 25, 1835.
